newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds close much lower on U.S.-led selloff.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds close much lower on U.S.-led selloff.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed much weaker in active trade on Wednesday, pulled lower with U.S. Treasuries following hawkish public testimony by U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, analysts said.

"The focus today has been fairly and squarely on the U.S. and everybody else has been carried along," said Jim Webber, director of fixed-income research with TD Securities Inc. "I don't think there's a particular Canadian story here at all."
Canada's 30-year bond fell C$1.50 to C$111.45 to yield 7.036 percent. The U.S. 30-year benchmark bond fell 1-19/32 to yield 6.78 percent.
The spread between the benchmark bonds narrowed to 26 basis points from 27 basis points at Tuesday's close.

Canadian and U.S. bond prices plunged this morning after Greenspan, speaking to the Senate Banking Committee as part of the semi-annual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, said a pre-emptive interest rate hike aimed at controlling inflation could not be ruled out.

Greenspan's hawkish testimony was followed by poorly received five-year bond auctions in Canada and the United States. In Canada, the Bank of Canada sold C$2.7 billion of five-year bonds due September 1, 2002.

The auction produced an average yield of 5.701 percent and an average price of C$99.064. Bids from primary dealers totalled C$5.9 billion, including C$61.9 million non-competitive tenders at the average yield.
A softer Canadian dollar also figured in Canadian bond market weakness, Webber said. Analysts said the Canadian dollar weakened amid concern that a near-term U.S. rate hike would weaken the currency.
In other prices, the Government of Canada's 7.0 percent bond due 2006 fell C$0.90 to C$104.38 to yield 6.388 percent. The U.S. 10-year bond fell 1-2/32 to yield 6.54 percent.
The negative spread between the bonds widened to 15 basis points from 14 basis points at the close of trading on Tuesday.
The three-month cash T-bill traded with a yield of 2.92 percent against the U.S. bill which yielded 5.19 percent.
